Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing integrated trait-based scaling theory to predict community change and forest function in light of global change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests store an enormous amount of carbon, with the Amazon alone accounting for 10% of the Earth's primary productivity. Changes in tropical forest productivity in response to drought are an important feedback in the carbon cycle; yet, we currently have a very incomplete understanding of how biomass, productivity, and species composition of these forests respond to changes in temperature and water availability. This project will take a new approach to understanding tropical forest drought responses by focusing on the relationships between plant functional traits, metabolic scaling theory, and climate drivers. Functional traits are easily measureable metrics that allow us to better predict plant growth, reproduction, and forest change. Metabolic scaling theory describes the relationships between the size of an organism, its growth rate, and temperature. This project will attempt to significantly advance our understanding of how tropical ecosystems respond to changes in temperature and precipitation. Researchers will use scaling theory to provide a predictive framework that links forest responses to drought with well understood plant traits measured using novel ground and remote sensing technology.

This project will assess changes in productivity in response to drought, as well as tree mortality and forest dieback. This will be accomplished using both field measurements as well as pre-existing LIDAR and hyperspectral remote sensing data from forests across an elevation gradient in the Peruvian Amazon. Specifically, researchers will use a suite of plant functional traits to provide detailed, 3D maps of forest canopy structure and the spatial distribution of traits. The novel scaling theory developed with these data (Trait Driver Theory, TDT) will then be used to predict ecosystem function from changes in trait distributions over time in response to drought. The project will also involve a field experiment to simulate drought with throughfall collectors to help parameterize TDT model functions. The TDT results will also be compared to predictions from the ecosystem demography model ED2. Model code, images, and algorithms will be made available in public repositories, and any new plant functional trait data will be added to global databases. The project will provide training for several post-doctoral researchers, undergraduate students, and K-12 science teachers and will use the GEM Network Geoweb Portal for outreach to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes - 

One of the largest uncertainties in global carbon cycle predictions is the response of tropical vegetation to drought. To make progress on this, there is an urgent need to develop a predictive framework that translates changes in species community composition to changes in ecosystem biomass, productivity, and biogeochemical function. To this end, our NSF funded project addressed three specific objectives (see below).

By addressing these objectives our research significantly addresses a limitation in ecological science - how to predict how forests have and will continue to respond to changes in temperature and precipitation. Our approach focused on plant traits related to physiology and growth. Our work is helping to advance theory for predicting ecosystem responses to global change and thereby contribute to the urgent need of tools to forecast the response of. The development of theory-driven and prediction generating research has the potential to fill important gaps in our basic understanding of how to scale basic plant processes such as transpiration, carbon flux, plant growth, carbon balance, and tree harvesting across changing environments.

Our overriding thesis focused on assessing if variation in ecosystem dynamics will be better predicted by the linkage between the environment (projected by Global Circulation Models (GCMs) and alternatives) and plant functional traits (e.g., optimal temperature for growth, leaf traits, maximal stomatal conductance) than by any other set of variables, including species averages, non-functional traits, biodiversity levels, etc.

Our proposed research consisted of three specific objectives.

We focused on linking and expanding on a series of tropical dataset collected in local communities and ecosystems with remotely sensed platforms that rely on cutting edge theory. Each objective related to assessing the predictions and assumptions of theory using five unique and detailed sets of data acrossan elevational gradient in the Perúvian tropics and a long-term forest dynamic plot in Costa Rica in response to drought.

1: Develop a theoretical framework (Trait Driver Theory, or TDT) to predict community and ecosystem productivity and diversity in response to changes in temperature and water availability.

2: Integrate key climatic drivers and associated plant traits for tropical forest productivity and mortality into an already existing database, to then use TDT to predict present ecosystem function.

3: Further assess and refine TDT via field work and experimentation and predictions for climate change from GCMs to predict future ecosystem responses to climate change.

An important component of our proposal was to leveraging local field data and remote sensing data in order to map local and landscape variation in plant functional traits and forest biomass from remotely sensed LIDAR, hyperspectral data, and satellite data. In deed, major breakthroughs have been made to accurately map leaf and canopy traits via remote sensing. We utilized the Carnegie Airborne Observatory (CAO), in several aspects of our work.

This combination of linking field data and remote sensing presents a unique opportunity to use TDT to explicitly predict forest community and ecosystem responses to drought in the tropics. Further, our approach to empirically assess predictions made from theory will focus on an iterative, improving process with feedback between theory toward better predictive theory via an ever-improving three-step cyclical process—(i) The development of general theory to derive the trait, productivity, and diversity relationships observed in empirical data; (ii) An assessment of assumptions and predictions made from theory, and (iii) A fine-tuning of predictions on the basis of departures from theory. Below we describe how we will integrate these data sets to achieve our three main project goals.

As the effects of climate change take place at an increasing pace, we are in urgent need of tools for communicating and planning about the future of biodiversity. Plants are major mediators and indicators of environmental change. Trees are an important driver of carbon stocks and forest transpiration is the biggest component of annual evapotranspiration. Our understanding of the future of tropical forests will depend upon an understanding of the responses of forest communities to disturbances and changes in climate, and the variation in these responses across different tree functional types, climates and soil conditions.   Further, in addition to our education outreach amd strengthening international relationships with Peruvian students and colleagues., our work will inform global change studies and conservation planning. The theory that we developed is informing how global change will influence ecosystem services important to society. In the face of climate change and an extinction crisis, theoretical approaches that can predict how ecological systems and diversity will respond are greatly needed.  The development of theory-driven and prediction-generating research fills important gaps in our basic understanding of how to scale basic plant processes such as water and carbon flux but also tree harvesting. Our proposed theory improves predictions regarding forestry, agriculture, and the community and ecosystem ecology changes that are caused by changes in individual plants.
